cleaned_text: Programs and Support Services May - August 2023 Sidney Kimmel Cancer CenterThe Cancer Support and Welcome Center at Jefferson Health wants you to know you are not alone, and we are here to partner with you and help you navigate your diagnosis and treatment. We understand that cancer is only part of your narrative. We are here to offer a range of supportive care programming including elements of the new field of integrative oncology. Our programs are designed to bring people with cancer, as well as those caring for someone with cancer, together, to foster community, educate and offer tools to help you understand and manage a diagnosis of cancer. Our programming is free to anyone impacted by cancer and keeps diversity, equity, inclusion, justice, and belonging as key values and commitments for our patients and for ourselves. We are committed to providing you and your family with support and will continue to expand and evolve our programming to meet the needs of our patients and families. If interested in registering for any of the programs included in this brochure please contact The Cancer Support and Welcome Center at 215-955-1800 or email us at cancersupportcenter@jefferson.edu or click directly on the links below to register. Hours of Operation: Monday to Friday 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Phone: 215-955-1800 E-Mail: CancerSupportCenter@Jefferson.edu For more information, visit www.Jefferson.edu/CancerSupportSUPPORTIVE GROUPS AND NETWORKING PROGRAMS: Allogeneic Blood and Marrow Transplant Education Class for Patients and their Caregivers Select Wednesdays of the month May 24, June 7, July 12, August 23 12:00 p.m.- 2:00 p.m. This virtual class is recommended for individuals and their caregivers who are preparing for, or considering, an allogeneic (receiving cells from someone else) blood stem cell transplant as a treatment option. This class will help you prepare for the stem cell transplant process. You and your caregiver will learn about what to expect during your hospitalization and after being discharged from the hospital. Please contact a Bone Marrow Transplant Coordinator at 215-503-7711 if you are interested in attending a class to check eligibility. Register in advance for this meeting: https://tinyurl.com/AlloSpring2023Autologous Blood and Marrow Transplant Education Class for Patients and their Caregivers Select Wednesdays of the month May 10, June 21, July 19, August 2 12:00 p.m. - 2:00 p.m. This virtual class is recommended for individuals and their caregivers preparing for, or considering, an autologous (receiving a transplant from yourself) stem cell transplant as a treatment option. This class will help prepare you for the stem cell transplant process. You and your caregiver will learn about what to expect during your hospitalization and after being discharged from the hospital. Please contact a Bone Marrow Transplant Coordinator at 215-503-7711 if you are interested in attending a class and to check eligibility. Register in advance for this meeting: https://tinyurl.com/AUTOBMTSpring2023 Bereavement Support Group Tuesdays; August 8 through September 12 4:30 p.m.- 6:00 p.m. Going through a loss is difficult and personally challenging. This six-session group is for adults 18 and older who are grieving the loss of a loved one who has died from cancer. Please join us as we share experiences of grief in a safe and supportive environment and help you move towards healing. Registration is required: https://tinyurl.com/bereavementgroup2023 Once registered, a social worker will reach out to complete group intake form. Virtual Only Program In Person Only Program Hybrid Program In Person and VirtualOn-Site Health and Safety Measures Universal Masking: Everyone is required to wear a mask while in the center. If you arrive without a mask we will provide you with one. Physical Distancing: Everyone must maintain a distance of at least six feet from each other. Cleaning: The center is cleaned professionally daily and tables will be wiped down between gatherings. ICON KEY: 1 2Virtual and on-site programs are indicated throughout this guide. We recognize in-person programs may not be the best choice for all participants at this time and encourage you to consult your healthcare team if you have questions about your safety.Brain Tumor Support Group at Jefferson Thursday, May 11 6:30 p.m. - 8:00 p.m. Our brain tumor caregiver support group provides a safe space to connect with others caring for or living with a brain tumor. The group provides emotional and practical support. Patients, families, and friends are all invited to attend free of charge. For more information, contact: lauren.barbieri@jefferson.edu Register in advance for this meeting: https://tinyurl.com/Braintumormay11 Brain Tumor Support Group at Jefferson The following Thursdays: June 8, July 13, August 10 6:30 p.m. - 8:00 p.m. The group provides emotional and practical support. Patients, families, and friends are all invited to attend free of charge. For more information, contact: lauren.barbieri@jefferson.edu Register in advance for this meeting: https://tinyurl.com/ThursBrainTumorSupportCare for the Caregiver First and Third Wednesdays of the month: May 3, May 17, June 7, June 21, July 5, July 19, August 2, August 16 12:00 p.m. - 1:00 p.m. This drop-in group is meant to provide support for cancer caregivers facing challenges such as changes or transitions in care - a new cancer diagnosis, new treatment, change in treatment, discharge from the hospital, or ending a treatment. These challenges can be stressful for both patients and caregivers. An interdisciplinary team (an oncology nurse and social worker) will lead this support and education group aimed at supporting those caring for a loved one with cancer. Register in advance for this group: https://tinyurl.com/CarefortheCaregiver2023Esophagectomy Survivorship and Support Group Wednesday, August 16 4:00 p.m. - 5:30 p.m. From newly diagnosed patients to veteran survivors, all patients and caregivers are welcome in our Esophagectomy Support Group to share messages of hope for life before and after esophagectomy. The concept of a major surgery such as an esophagectomy can be intimidating and overwhelming. At this quarterly meeting, confusion and frustration are met with solid answers, new hope, and confidence. For more information, contact: Sung.Whang@jefferson.edu Register in advance for this group: https://tinyurl.com/Esophagectomy2023 FIGHTING MEN Fighting CANCER: a Virtual Prostate Cancer Support Group Virtual May 2, June 6, July 5, August 1 7:00 p.m. - 8:00 p.m. Have you had prostate cancer, been recently diagnosed, or are interested in learning more about prostate cancer? Join us on Zoom for a confidential education and support group. We will discuss helpful information for survivors, patients, and caregivers, as well as have an open discussion to share experiences with the disease. Occasional guest speakers also provide useful information. To register, contact Joe Musumeci: joe4seeds@gmail.com or call 856-278-1679.FIGHTING MEN Fighting CANCER: IN PERSON Prostate Cancer Support Group Third Monday of the month: May 15, June 19, July 17, August 21 7:00 p.m. - 8:00 p.m. American Legion Post in Williamstown, NJ Have you had prostate cancer, been recently diagnosed, or interested in learning more about prostate cancer? Join us on Zoom for a confidential education and support group. We will discuss helpful information for survivors, patients, and caregivers, and have an open discussion to share experiences with the disease. Occasional guest speakers also provide useful information. To register, contact Joe Musumeci: joe4seeds@gmail.com or call 856-278-1679. General Breast Cancer Support Group Every other Tuesday: May 19, June 2, June 16, June 30, July 14, July 28 12:00 p.m. - 1:15 p.m. This is a session for people with breast cancer (stages 0-3) to learn about all the resources available to them for financial assistance, transportation, food, housing, mental health, legal assistance, and much more. Participants can give and receive support from each other or share resources and information. Facilitated by Celeste Vaughan-Briggs, LCSW, and Joslyn group: https://tinyurl.com/BCsupport2023 or call 215-503-3221. 3 4Laryngectomy Support Group Third Thursday of the month: May 18, June 15, July 20, August 17 12:00 p.m. - 1:00 p.m. This Laryngectomy support group provides information, education, and psychosocial support to patients, caregivers, and friends. Facilitated by Lora Rhodes, LCSW, and Sarah Adams, CCC-SLP. For registration information, contact Sarah Adams, CCC-SLP: sarah.adams@jefferson.edu Metastatic Breast Cancer Support and Education Group The following Fridays: May 26, June 9 & 23, July 7 & 21, August 4 12:00 p.m. - 1:15 p.m. This is a support and education group for people who are diagnosed with stage IV metastatic breast cancer. The group is for patients to give and receive support from each other and to share resources and information. Experts will be brought in for each specialized topic. Facilitated by Celeste Vaughan-Briggs, or call 215-503-3221Music Therapy Support Group Second Month of the month: May 8, June 12, July 10, August 14 1:00 p.m. - 2:00 p.m. The music therapy support group will employ a variety of music-based activities to promote mindfulness, discussion, self-expression, community, and social support. In-person participation is strongly encouraged but arrangements will be made to include remote participants. Themes and activities will vary from week to week according to the needs and interests of those present. No previous experience with music or music therapy is required. "Music is a world within itself with a language we all understand" - Stevie Wonder. Led by a Music Therapist. One-on-one sessions and consultations will be available by appointment on a limited basis. Register in advance for this meeting: https://tinyurl.com/MusicTherapyGroup2023 Orbital Support Group Thursdays, July 20, October 19 3:30 p.m. - 4:30 p.m. This quarterly support group is aimed at providing education and support to anyone impacted by orbital cancer and have undergone an orbital exenteration surgery for cancer (eye removal) Facilitated by: Lisa Capparella MSS, LCSW, OSW-C & Maureen Murphy, this meeting: https://tinyurl.com/OrbitalSupportGroup2023Primary and Metastatic Ocular Melanoma (OM) Support Group (Online/Telephone) First Wednesday of the month: May 3, June 7, July 5, August 2 1:00 p.m. - 2:00 p.m. This group, in partnership with the Melanoma Research Foundation's CURE OM, provides virtual support to individuals diagnosed with primary and metastatic ocular melanoma (OM). The group is facilitated by a licensed social worker and includes a mix of educational and wellness information, as well as space to connect with other patients for emotional support and companionship. For registration information, email Molly Vocino, LCSW education@melanoma.org Young Adult Group First Wednesday of the month: May 3, June 7, August 2 5:30 p.m. - 7:00 p.m. This is not your grandmother's support group. Topics include dating, employment, fertility, and everything else that affects people in the 18-45 age range. Facilitated by Jodi Sandos, Jodi.Sandos@jefferson.edu or call 215-503-7711. 5 6 NOTES & QUESTIONSRestorative Yoga and Meditation Series The following Thursdays: May 4, May 18, June 15, June 29, July 13, July 27, August 17, August 31 12:30 p.m. - 1:30 p.m. This yoga series will include supported postures for ease of practice while building strength and awareness. This method of yoga offers gentle stretching, profound opening, and effortless release of stress. We will learn to breathe deeply, rest fully, and live mindfully. Props are needed: a yoga mat, blocks, blanket (household items such as firm pillows, hardcover books, blankets, and a sturdy chair can be used). If you'd like to get help with your alignment and tips to help you improve your experience, set up your device with your camera on. If any accommodation is needed, please reach out to cancersupportcenter@jefferson.edu and we will connect you with the instructor. Facilitated by Mary Garbesi, Certified Iyengar Yoga Teacher, Certified International Association of Yoga Therapist Register in advance for this class: https://tinyurl.com/RestorativeYogaSpring2023 INTEGRATIVE MIND AND BODY WELLNESS PROGRAMS: Intro to Integrative Oncology Session: 4 Part Series Fridays May 19, June 16, July 21 & August 18 12:00 p.m. -1:00 p.m. Join us monthly for a discussion on a variety of Integrative Oncology Techniques and evidence-based treatment for managing symptoms of cancer treatment. Discussions will focus on Chinese Medicine, Acupuncture, Yoga and more. Register in advance: https://tinyurl.com/IntegrativeOncologySeries2023Meditation in Community: Connecting to Inner Wellbeing with The 3 Doors Every Tuesday: May 23 through June 20th 12:00 p.m.- 1:00 p.m. In the warmth of community, learn The 3 Doors meditation practices of body, breath, and mind that can be a source of daily support. This course was developed in collaboration with The Jung Center's Mind Body Spirit Institute, and these practices have been taught and researched at MD Anderson Cancer Center. Calm the anxious mind, relieve stress, shift your perspective around pain, and discover a more restful, aware, and connected state of being with these simple and powerful methods. Each session will include time for teaching and guided practice, as well as sharing and discussion. This course is open to individuals with cancer, caregivers, and family members, and all participants are eligible for future Cancer and Caregivers community practice sessions offered by The 3 Doors. Presented in partnership with Jefferson Sidney Kimmel Cancer Center and The 3 Doors, an international nonprofit dedicated to transforming lives through meditation in community: www.the3doors.org. Facilitated by 3 Doors Senior Teachers: Alejandro Chaoul, PhD and Gabriel Rocco, MA Register in advance for this class: https://tinyurl.com/3DoorsMeditation 7 8 1:1 Massage/Reiki Session (20 minutes) Thursday, May 25 Tuesday, July 11 Tuesday, August 1 Sessions available between: 10:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. Each 20-minute private session will include 10 minutes of a chair massage and 10 minutes of Reiki therapy by a licensed massage/Reiki therapist. Patients/Caregivers will be seen by appointment only. We ask that you arrive at least 5 minutes before your scheduled appointment. Facilitated by Sharon Edelman LMT, RM. Registration is required and spots are limited: email cancersupportcenter@jefferson.edu or call 215-955-1800 to check availability. Lipstick Angels Tuesday, June 6 3:00 p.m. - 5:00 p.m. Join the Lipstick Angels for a totally immersive Virtual Clean Beauty & Wellness class via Zoom! Oncology-trained professional makeup artists and estheticians teach a holistic and clean approach to beauty and wellness, covering everything from aromatherapy, a hydrating facial, a complete makeup look, and more! Each participant will receive a full, complimentary set of products to use during the class. All genders are welcome! Register in advance for this workshop: https://tinyurl.com/Lipstickangels2023 Coping Through Poetry: Healing Verse Moments The following Wednesdays: June 14, July 12, August 9 12:00 p.m. - 1:00 p.m. Take a midday break and participate in the power of creative expression. No prior writing experience necessary! Writing is a healing art and a useful tool to help us cope with the complexities we carry in the moment. It is a way to give voice to the weight of our experiences and the joys we hold - to unearth, release, acknowledge, and celebrate what lies deepest in our hearts and minds and what we encounter daily. This workshop is an invitation to cancer patients, survivors, and caregivers to explore and write the stories you feel are important to tell during this challenging time. These guided interactive writing moments, led by two award-winning former Philadelphia poets laureate, offer fun and accessible writing exercises, prompts, and selected readings to help participants express themselves and explore their inner voice. Whether you are a patient, survivor, or caregiver, whether you have writing experience or you don't, this workshop is the perfect opportunity to experience the healing act of writing. It is a dynamic way to document the triumphs and the hardships of the cancer experience and to explore how this creative outlet can offer personal transformation and healing. Register in advance for this workshop: https://tinyurl.com/HealingPoetry2023Your Crown and Glory Workshop Tuesday, July 18 12:00 p.m. - 1:30 p.m. Your Crown and Glory Workshop is an introduction to the world of beauty self-care when dealing with hair loss. This class will offer a complete Guide To Hair Extensions, Wigs, and Accessories for those experiencing hair loss due to chemotherapy. This educational workshop provides the following: · Information about how to manage and cope with hair loss · Detailed instructions on choosing the perfect wig and potential insurance coverage of your wig · Head-wear and scalp helpful tips and techniques Facilitated by Asya Richardson, Founder and CEO of Indian Princess Hair (IPH) https://indianprincesshair.com/ Register in advance for this workshop: https://tinyurl.com/CrownGlory23 Family Movie @ Noon Tuesday, August 1 12:00 p.m. Cancer Support and Welcome Center Please join us for a family movie at noon, here at the Cancer Support and Welcome Center. This is offered to families with children of all ages, preferably those above the age of 3. We know that summertime can be stressful, having everyone at home, so let our family movie at noon be an opportunity for you and your family to get out of the house, connect with others, and enjoy a movie. Light refreshments will be offered as well as comfortable pillows, blankets, and standard chairs. We hope to see you there! Register in advance for this event: email cancersupportcenter@jefferson.edu or call 215-955-1800.A Course in Mindfulness Meditation Tuesday mornings: April 25 through June 13 9:30 a.m. - 12:00 p.m. OR Thursdays evenings: April 27 through June 15 6:30 p.m. - 9:00 p.m. *Both sessions include a retreat day on Sunday, June 4 10:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. Cost: $495 Mindfulness is a meditative process that quiets the mind and releases physical distress. Through mindfulness you can experience greater vitality and well-being in the present moment. Participants are asked to make a strong commitment to attend all sessions, and to practice meditation/relaxation techniques on a daily basis throughout the eight-week program. For more information: https://www.jeffersonhealth.org/conditions- and-treatments/mindfulness-based-stress- reduction Email mbsr@jefferson.edu to request registration information Specify the session you would like to attend (Tuesday a.m. or Thursday p.m.). 9 10 NOTES & QUESTIONSEDUCATIONAL CLASSES: EDUCATIONAL CLASSES: Brain Tumor Awareness Month Programs Topic: Treatment of Glioblastoma in the Era of Immunotherapy Wednesday, May 3 Presentation: 6:00 p.m. - 6:45 p.m. Q&A: 6:45 p.m. - 7:00 p.m. Presenters: David Andrews, MD & Kevin Judy, MD Moderator: Christopher Farrell, MD Topic: Benign Tumors of the Brain and Skull Base Wednesday, May 10 Presentation: 6:00 p.m. - 6:45 p.m. Q&A: 6:45 p.m. - 7:00 p.m. Presenters: Christopher Farrell, MD; James Evans, MD; & Wenyin Shi, MD Moderator: David Andrews, MD Topic: Standard of Care or Clinical Trial? Wednesday, May 17 Presentation: 6:00 p.m. - 6:45 p.m. Q&A: 6:45 p.m. - 7:00 p.m. Presenters: Nina Martinez, MD & Iyad Alnahhas, MD Moderator: Jon Glass, MD Topic: Living with a Brain Tumor: Navigating the New Normal Wednesday, May 31 Presentation: 6:00 p.m. - 6:45 p.m. Q&A: 6:45 p.m. - 7:00 p.m. Presenters: Noel Mitchell, MSW, advance for this series: JeffersonHealth.org/BrainTumorWebinars (You will be prompted to indicate which - or all - sessions you wish to attend.)Coping with Cancer: Skills to Balance Uncertainty with Hope Tuesday, May 9 12:00 p.m. - 1:00 p.m. How do we manage life with cancer and cope even in tough moments? Join Dr. Virginia O'Hayer, who will utilize skills from Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) and Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT). Both methods have been proven to be effective in dealing with life's challenges. Dr. O'Hayer will discuss ways to change how we respond to unpredictable and uncontrollable situations, even when we can't change them. You can regain a sense of control and emotional balance by learning how to live the life you want to be living NOW, balance strong emotions, and accept what can't be changed. This webinar will help teach you skills to deal with difficult emotions. Facilitated by C. Virginia F. O'Hayer, Ph.D. and Lisa Capparella, MSS, LCSW. Register in advance for this webinar: https://tinyurl.com/CopingCancerMovement as Medicine Program Wednesday, May 10 12:00 p.m. - 1:00 p.m. This session is all about movement and learning what works best for you and your body. Led by Erin Kelly, DO, a physician medicine and rehabilitation (PM&R) and palliative care physician, Dr. Kelly reviews the evidence and recommendations for safe physical activity before, during or after cancer treatment and introduces cancer rehabilitation and survivorship, who can benefit and how to access it at Jefferson. Register in advance for this webinar: https://tinyurl.com/MovementasMedicine23 Pharmacy Lecture Series Topic: Hormonal Therapy Thursday, May 11 1:00 p.m. - 1:30 p.m. Hormonal therapies may be used alone, or in combinations with other anti-cancer agents, for the treatment of certain cancers. In this lecture, we will discuss commonly used hormonal therapies and potential side effects they may cause. 11 12 Pharmacy Lecture Series (Cont.) Topic: Vitamins, Supplements, and Oncology Thursday, July 13 1:00 p.m. - 1:30 p.m. We will review common vitamins and supplements that should be avoided during cancer treatments, as well as share resources that can provide more information, and answer any questions related to alternative therapies. Topic: Immunotherapy Thursday, August 10 1:00 p.m. - 1:30 p.m. Immunotherapy has taken cancer treatment to a new level, training the immune system to attack cancer cells instead of "traditional chemotherapy" which attacks cancer directly. Yet, like all treatments, it comes with its own risk of side effects. Come learn about unique side effects to immunotherapy and how to manage them should they occur during treatment. Topic: Cancer Treatments and Neuropathy Thursday, September 14 1:00 p.m. - 1:30 p.m. In this talk, we'll review how cancer drugs cause neuropathy and discuss how we can best treat it. All sessions facilitated by Rose DiMarco, PharmD, BCPS, BCOP Register in advance for this webinar series: https://tinyurl.com/Pharmacylecture2023 (You will be prompted to indicate which - or all - sessions you wish to attend.) Managing Long Term Side Effects of Cancer Treatment Monday, August 7 12:00 p.m. - 1:00 p.m. Facilitated by: Karon Martyn, MSN, ANP-BC, AOCNP As a cancer survivor, you're ready to move on with life after cancer. However, side effects from your disease or aggressive treatment methods may interfere with your quality of life. Some may be temporary, and others may last a lifetime. Learn more about the common side effects faced by cancer survivors like you, and how to manage them effectively. Register in advance for this meeting: https://tinyurl.com/longtermeffects23Coping with Cancer- Related Anxiety and Insomnia Monday, May 22 12:00 p.m. - 1:00 p.m. In this session, we will discuss insomnia and anxiety and explain why cancer patients so commonly experience these problems. We will discuss recommended treatments and strategies to improve symptoms and help you cope both during treatment and in survivorship. We will cover common medications for these symptoms, and why some non-pharmacologic strategies are often the most effective. Facilitated by Molly Hanson, CRNP, Emily Hajjar, PharmD, MS, BCPS, BCACP, BCGP, class: https://tinyurl.com/Anxiety-and-Insomnia2023 What Matters Most? Two-part Personalize Care Decision Workshop Monday, June 26 and Monday, July 17 12:00 p.m. - 1:00 p.m. Cancer Support and Welcome Center This free two-part workshop is for people with a cancer diagnosis and their loved ones focused on creating a personalized care plan that will enable you to: Honor your health care wishes Have a safe place to ask questions Complete a new or revised Advance Directive for Healthcare (Complementary Notary services will be provided) Facilitated by Ramona Sitko, MSW LSW & Lisa Capparella MSS, for this workshop: email cancersupportcenter@jefferson.edu or call 215-955-1800.Session 1: Monday, June 26 12:00 p.m. - 1:00 p.m. Learn about Advance Directive Forms and which one works best for YOU (we will offer 3 different documents), what questions to ask yourself and your family, things to consider about your wishes, and how to complete the form. Session 2: Monday, July 17 12:00 p.m. - 1:00 p.m. Bring your completed or partially completed form to the workshop, ask any additional questions you or your family may have, and have your form witnessed and notarized on- site at no cost to you. A copy of your document will be uploaded to your medical record. Managing Long Term & Late Side Effects of Cancer Treatment Thursday, June 29 12:00 p.m.- 1:00 p.m. Facilitated by: Cynthia Wheeler, CRNP As a cancer survivor, you're ready to move on with life after cancer. However, side effects from your disease or aggressive treatment methods may interfere with your quality of life. Some may be temporary, and others may last a lifetime. Learn more about the common side effects faced by cancer survivors like you, and how to manage them effectively. Register in advance: https://tinyurl.com/LongTermCancerJune2023Managing Long Term & Late Side Effects of Cancer Treatment Tuesday, July 18 5:00 p.m. - 6:00 p.m. Facilitated by: Linda Ferguson, MSN, CRNP As a cancer survivor, you're ready to move on with life after cancer. However, side effects from your disease or aggressive treatment methods may interfere with your quality of life. Some may be temporary, and others may last a lifetime. Learn more about the common side effects faced by cancer survivors like you, and how to manage them effectively. Register in advance: https://tinyurl.com/LateSideEffects2023 How the Public Moves Clinical Trials Forward Tuesday, July 25 12:00 p.m. - 1:00 p.m. Facilitated by: Jeanne Morrison, BSN, RN, CCRP and Nicole Hartman, MPH Clinical trials depend on partnering with the public to advance science. Join us for an educational session on clinical trials and what role they may play in your life. Register in advance for this meeting: https://tinyurl.com/ClinicalTrials23 13 14 NOTES & QUESTIONS4 - 4:45 p. m.Registra tion, Sponsorship Exhibits and Opportunity to Meet and Mingle 4:45 - 6 p.m. Welcome R emarks, Dinner & Speak ers Featuring: Wm. Kevin K elly, DO Chair W elcome C enter James Bonder , Sr. Motivational Speak er and Survivor o f Stomach CancerCelebration of Life Thursday, June 8, 2023 | 4 to 7 p .m. (1020 Locust Street, Philadelphia, PA 19107) Please join us as we come together for this inspirational event featuring special guests and clinicians from Sidney Kimmel Cancer Center, focused on celebrating you and your caretakers. 24TH ANNUAL 24TH ANNUAL CANCER SURVIVORSHIP CELEBRATION: A D AY OF COMMUNITY AND CONNE CTIONSidney Kimmel Cancer Center For more information and to register, please Scan the Q R Code or visit: https://tinyurl.com/SKCCcelebration23 Life with Cancer: A Panel Discussion Coping with Physical, Emotional and Financial Impact Erin K elly, DO C. Virginia O'Hayer , PhD Director , Clinic for Behavioral Medicine Nathan Handley , MD , Integra Medicine Santiago, BBA , CRCS Manager , Oncology Financial Advocacy 6 - 6:45 p. m. Celebra tion Continues with Community and Connection Conclude the evening by enjoying more exhibitor tables, a photo booth, participating in a d rum circle, snuggling with a p et therap y dog and much more. 6:45 - 7 p. m. Event Conclusion & Closing R emarks Maysa Abu Khala f, MD , MBA er es Deputy Dir ector , Enterprise Canc Breast Medical Onc ology Departmen t of Medical Onc , Division o f Solid T umor Asplundh Cancer Pavilion | Jefferson Health 3941 Commerce Ave, Willow Grove, PA 19090 Creativity and Connection, by Mindful Arts at Asplundh Asplundh Cancer Center, Community Education Room Open Art Studio The following Wednesdays: May 3, 10, 17 12:00 p.m. - 2:00 p.m. This open art studio is held in a bright sunny space next to nature, providing community support through a shared art experience. This studio is for current or post-treatment patients looking to connect and express themselves. The studio is led by Alex Orgera, a community arts educator and current graduate student of Expressive Arts Therapy. To register, please email michelle.balcer@jefferson.edu PROGRAMS AT OUR CARE HUBS: Guided Breath Drum Circle Mondays, 5:30 p.m. - 6:30 p.m. May 1 through June 5 (6 sessions) Led by a Board-Certified Music Therapist, this drum circle will focus on body and breath connections through rhythmic drumming. Rhythms and techniques will be taught in a way that is accessible to all levels of skill. Give your body a vibro-acoustic massage in a supportive community circle! This class is open to past and current cancer patients and their caregivers. It is adaptable to all stages of self- care, treatment, recovery, and remission. No experience necessary! Drum provided or bring your own. To register, please email michelle.balcer@jefferson.edu Changing Bodies: Exploring Body Image & Health using Expressive Arts Thursdays, 4:00 p.m. - 5:00 p.m. May 11 through June 15 (6 sessions) This workshop will focus on redefining the relationship you have with your body. Led by an Expressive Arts Therapy graduate intern, who will guide you in using photography, sculpture, mixed-media, and body-based exercises to create a safe and supportive space to explore "Body Image." Give your body a voice! This is an opportunity to rewrite the narrative about what bodies should be and embrace the changes that bodies go through. This workshop is open to anyone affected by cancer treatment at some point in their lives. No experience necessary! Materials provided. Not necessary to attend all sessions. To register, please email michelle.balcer@jefferson.edu 17PROGRAMS AT OUR CARE HUBS: Women's Cancer Support Group Second Monday of the month June 12, July 10, August 14, September 11, October 9, November 13, December 11 4:30 p.m. - 6:00 p.m. The Women's Cancer Support Group is open to all women with a cancer diagnosis. Please join us to connect and share experiences about navigating life with cancer in a safe and supportive environment. This is a safe space to learn, share feelings, gather information, and talk about treatment, side effects, and the effects on children, family, friends and important relationships in your life. This group will be led by two oncology social workers to provide emotional and practical support and guidance. For more information and to register, please contact Andie Farnham, LSW, at 215-481-4517; or Denise Young, MS, MSW, LCSW, at 215-481-4360. Mindfulness Practice Group Fourth Friday of the Month June 23, July 28, August 25, September 22, October 27, November 24*, December 22 11:00 a.m. - 12:00 p.m. Please join us and learn more about mindfulness meditation practice. Open to patients and caregivers. No experience needed! Calm the anxious mind, relieve stress, shift your perspective around pain, and discover a more restful, aware, and connected state of being with simple and powerful methods. Each month we will take part in a different meditation practice then talk about our experiences. For more information and to register, please contact Andie Farnham, LSW, at 215-481-4517; or Denise at 215-481- 4360.Jefferson Program PA 19114 1:1 Massage/Reiki Session (20-minute sessions) Friday, August 4 10:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. Each 20-minute private session will include 10 minutes of a chair massage and 10 minutes of Reiki therapy by a licensed massage/Reiki therapist. Patients/Caregivers will be seen by appointment only. We ask that you arrive at least 5 minutes before your scheduled appointment. Facilitated by: Sharon Edelman LMT, RM Registration is required and spots are limited. To register, please call Constance West at 267-251-1377 or email Constance.West@Jefferson.edu New Jersey Cancer Survivor Day Sunday, June 4 11:00 a.m. - 2:00 p.m. To register: https://tinyurl.com/NJSurvivorday23 Helen's Angels Pink Ball Golf Tournament Monday, May 15 Register in advance for this meeting https://helensangels.org/pink-ball-tournament/ 19th Annual Patrick Shane Biddulph Golf Tournament Wednesday, May 17 Mercer County, NJ- For more information email Rachel.Vetesi@jefferson.edu Amy's Ride, Run, Walk Saturday, May 20 Link to Register: https:// amysriderunwalk.enmotive.com/events/ register/amy-s-ride-run-walk-2023- may-20-2023 SPECIAL EVENTS & COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS: Unite For Her Virtual Wellness Orientation Saturday, May 20 The event is open to breast cancer and gynecologic cancer patients. The goal of the Wellness Program is to introduce patients to integrative therapies designed to help women become fully restored during and after cancer treatment. Attendees will virtually meet with professionals and learn about the potential benefits of nutrition, yoga, acupuncture, and massage therapies. Upon registration for the Virtual Wellness Orientation Day, participants will receive a HER Care Box, including a Wellness Passport from Unite for HER for the therapies they feel would best assist them with restoring health as they continue their treatments. The Wellness Program and Passport therapies are free of charge and are worth up to $2,000 in value. You can begin to explore available integrative therapies by visiting uniteforher.org/integrative therapies. Registration is limited for this program and is intended for the personal needs and support of patients only. Register in advance for this meeting using this link or QR code: uniteforher.org/apply Gynecological Cancer Symposium Wednesday, September 13 4:00 p.m. - 6:00 p.m. 18NCI Designated Cancer Centers bring patients leading-edge treatment opportunities via clinical trials. To help you learn more about clinical trials, we've developed a brief video that you may review online. Watching the video is itself a clinical trial! You will be helping advance knowledge on how best to learn about cancer clinical trials by watching the video and answering some questions before and after watching the video. The whole process usually takes 15 minutes or less. If you are interested, please contact Iqra at ixs053@jefferson.edu or scan the QR code below: You will receive $20 for completing the entire study. We thank you for considering. Please feel free to ask your doctor about clinical trials and learn more. A Community-Based Educational Intervention to Improve Clinical Trials Knowledge PI: Ana Maria Lopez, MD, MPH, MACP, FRCP What are the goals: Educate communities about clinical trials to increase awareness and diversify the population who participate in clinical trials What will participants be asked to do: Watch a brief online (10-15 minute) video Answer questions before and after watching the video Contact Info: Iqra Siddiqui: 267-586-1886 Iqra.Siddiqui@jefferson.edu RESEARCH STUDIES AND CLINICAL TRIALS: Exploring Inflammation and Social determinants (EXIST) Study in African American Breast Cancer Patients PI: Nicole Simone, MD What are the goals: To determine the correlation between systemic inflammation and social determinants of health in Black or African American breast cancer patients. Participation in this research will be very helpful to better understand how to help people with your same disease. What will participants be asked to do: Attend one in-person visit Respond to questionnaires Complete a physical exam Additional study procedures Contact Info: EXIST-Breast-Cancer@jefferson.edu Testing Early Treatment for Patients with High-Risk Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) or Small Lymphocytic Leukemia (SLL) PI: Gina Keiffer, MD What are the goals: To find out if early treatment can help people with certain types of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) or small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) live longer and have a better quality of life. What will participants be asked to do: Participants must have cancer diagnosis within the last 12 months and have not received any therapy for their cancer Randomly assigned into one of two groups and receive treatment based on the group assigned Have regular tests and health checks Complete additional study procedures Contact Info: Kara Ryan: 215-519-8920 Kara.Ryan@jefferson.edu Clinical Trials Finder Jefferson conducts cutting edge research to advance science and medical treatments globally. Research is one of the main pillars of Jefferson. In an effort to raise awareness, educate the public, and showcase studies that are actively recruiting participants, Jefferson created a resource that provides a high-level overview of Clinical Trials. It also allows the public to browse both Oncology and Non- Oncology related studies. By participating in clinical research, you are investing in yourself, your community, and the future of research. It is our partnerships with our volunteers that help create breakthroughs and further medical knowledge and treatments. We pride ourselves on creating a research environment based on respect, trust, and compassion between our teams and volunteers and work together as one to improve the outcomes of many. Our updated trial finder has a variety of clinical trials, both for cancer and non-cancer health matters. These can include prevention trials, quality of life trials, screening trials, diagnostic trials and therapeutic trials, among others.For information on support services available at other Jefferson Health locations, please contact: Asplundh Cancer Pavilion | Jefferson Health Katie Lundy, MSW, 481-2579 or Northeast www.JeffersonHealth.org/clinical-specialties/ cancer Jefferson Cherry Hill Hospital, Jefferson Stratford Hospital, Jefferson Washington Township Hospital Cherry Hill Danielle McLaney MSW, LSW 856-684-0165 www.JeffersonHealth.org/clinical-specialties/ cancer JEFFERSON HEALTH 21 22 RESEARCH STUDIES AND CLINICAL TRIALS: SKCC Oncology Navigation While under the care of the Sidney Kimmel Cancer Center, you have access to a team of navigators ready to assist you along the way. The SKCC Oncology Navigation Team will be glad to help you arrange appointments, understand what to expect, and coordinate your care. Navigators will share information about the SKCC support services available to you and will help you get connected to them. You can connect with a navigator by calling 215-955-8014. Smoking Cessation Program Learn more about the benefits of quitting and how our program can help you quit and stay quit safely and effectively. This is a 6-month program to support you. Services include: Personalized Counseling Sessions with a tobacco treatment specialist Behavioral replacement therapy Direct Referral to PA/NJ state quit lines Nicotine Replacement Therapy Medications as needed For more information please contact, Debbie Diep; 215-866-8124 or email Jeff.tobacco@jefferson.edu Mobile Cancer Screening The Mobile Cancer Screening Van is the latest in a long line of innovation and technology advancements from the Sidney Kimmel Cancer Center. Thanks to a generous gift from Dietz & Watson, this mobile cancer screening van was designed specifically for Jefferson Health and provides a convenient way to receive a cancer screening with the same imaging technology we use at our facilities. Private changing rooms and mammogram area. On average your mammogram takes less than 10 minutes. Timely screening results are provided to you and your primary care. A certified mammography technologist from Jefferson Health will perform each mammogram. Other cancer screenings will be performed by physicians or providers from Jefferson Health. If you would like to schedule the Mobile Cancer Screening Van for your organizations, please email SKCCscreeningvan@jefferson.edu or call 215-503-9673 for materials. https://hospitals.jefferson.edu/departments- and-services/sidney-kimmel-cancer-center/ mobile-cancer-screening.html NAVIGATION: NOTES & QUESTIONSNOTES & QUESTIONSSupport Services The Sidney Kimmel Cancer Center at Jefferson is your partner on the road to recovery. As we navigate this journey together, we understand that cancer can affect many aspects of your life. That's why the Jefferson staff works with you and your family to help you meet your physical and emotional needs during this difficult time. Supportive Services we offer: Oncology Social Workers Nutrition Counseling by Registered Dietitians Financial Assistance Services Fertility Preservation Psychiatric-Oncology/Counseling Buddy Program What can I expect from treatment? Does ANYONE know what I'm going through? Will my life ever be normal again? ASK a Buddy. This program is for newly diagnosed cancer patients to be matched with a trained cancer survivor who is specifically matched by diagnosis, treatment, age, and gender. Call 267-438-0574 if you would like to be matched with a "Buddy" or if you would like to become a "Buddy." Oncology Medical Home (OMH) An Oncology Medical Home (OMH) is a care delivery system that is physician-led, directing a team to provide patient and family support through the care journey from diagnosis, to treatment, and follow-up care. This physician-led team is primarily responsible for care coordination that enhances your care experience, clinical outcomes, and quality of life. What is Care Coordination? Communication within the practice team and other physicians and services caring for you include primary care physician; specialty providers; outside agencies like home care; rehabilitation; support services; and community resources. Education about your diagnosis, treatment, follow-up, and support services. Symptom triage support for easy access to the practice and providers to address your health concerns quickly to avoid emergency department visits or unplanned hospitalizations. Support through the care journey including initial diagnosis, treatment plan, symptom management, survivorship, and supportive care. One resource to help you manage all aspects of treatment.Cancer Support & Welcome Center The Cancer Support and Welcome Center promotes wellness and healing by providing you and your family with supportive care services and cancer-related information. A range of programs are free and offered to anyone living with cancer, regardless of where they receive care. The Cancer Support and Welcome Center is open Monday through Friday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. 914 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia, PA 19107 215-955-1800 | CancerSupportCenter@ jefferson.edu Clinical Trials A clinical trial is a type of research study that tests how well new medical approaches work. Jefferson offers a number of clinical trials. To find out if there is a clinical trial available that might be right for you ask your healthcare providers, visit our website, or contact the Sidney Kimmel Cancer Center Clinical Research Management Office at 215-955-1661. Jefferson.edu/ClinicalTrials Division of Supportive Medicine & Cancer Survivorship The Division of Supportive Medicine & Cancer Survivorship is available to help you while receiving treatment at Jefferson by addressing the issues that affect the quality of your life both during and after your cancer care. Topics addressed include the physical, emotional, social, financial, and spiritual impacts, among others. 215-955-1888 Legal Clinic for Cancer Patients Sessions are by appointment only on select Tuesdays. Registration required at 215-955- 1800 or cancersupportcenter@jefferson.edu Temple Legal Aid Office Lawyers and Legal Interns Representation is available for Philadelphia residents who meet Legal Aid's low-income criteria. Receive free legal advice and assistance. Advice is provided on many issues, including disability benefits, advance directives, powers of attorney, guardianship, estate planning, private disability insurance, housing, family law, health insurance, and discrimination.
